title-group.article-title: Longitudinal Changes in Suck-Swallow-Breathe, Oxygen Saturation, and Heart Rate Patterns in Term Breastfeeding Infants

article-meta.aff: 1School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, The University of Western Australia, Crawley, Western Australia

author-notes.corresp: Vanessa S. Sakalidis, School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, The University of Western Australia, M310, 35 Stirling Hwy, Crawley, Western Australia 6009, Australia Email: 10413297@student.uwa.edu.au

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Despite the differences in breastfeeding and bottle-feeding, our understanding of how suck-swallow-breathe (SSwB), oxygenation, and heart rate patterns change as the infant ages is based predominantly on bottle-feeding studies. Therefore, this study aimed to measure how SSwB, oxygenation, and heart rate patterns changed during the first 4 months of lactation in term breastfeeding infants.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Infants less than 1 month postpartum (n = 15) were monitored early in lactation and again later in lactation (2-4 months postpartum). Simultaneous recordings of vacuum, tongue movement, respiration, swallowing, oxygen saturation, and heart rate were made during both nutritive sucking and non-nutritive sucking during breastfeeding.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Infants transferred a similar amount of milk (P = .15) over a shorter duration later in lactation (P = .04). Compared to early lactation, suck bursts became longer (P < .001), pauses became shorter (P < .001), vacuum levels decreased (all P < .05), oxygen saturation increased (P < .001), and heart rate decreased (P < .001) later in lactation.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: This study confirmed that term infants become more efficient at breastfeeding as they age, primarily by extending their suck bursts and pausing less. Although infants demonstrated satisfactory SSwB coordination during early lactation, they showed a level of adaption or conditioning at later lactation by applying weaker vacuum levels and demonstrating improved cardiorespiratory responses.

p.italic: It is well known that infants become more efficient at breastfeeding as they age, however, how sucking, swallowing, breathing, and cardiorespiratory patterns change with age is unclear.

Infants became more efficient at feeding by increasing their suck burst lengths and decreasing the time spent pausing. A conditioning effect showed infants applied weaker vacuums and improved their cardiorespiratory responses over time.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Suck-swallow-breathe (SSwB) coordination is an innate reflex in the healthy term infant and is critical for effective feeding.1 It is often assumed that the physiology and maturation of breastfeeding patterns are similar to those of bottle-feeding, however, bottle-feeding infants often exhibit lower oxygen saturation and irregular coordination of sucking and breathing.2-4 Therefore, given that the majority of research pertaining to SSwB is based on bottle-fed infants, it is clear that the findings cannot be extrapolated to breastfeeding term infants.2-4

Key physiological changes that occur both over the course of lactation and within a single breastfeed may influence the coordination of SSwB. The initiation of copious milk secretion occurs 30-40 hours postpartum,5 such that infant milk transfer increases from less than 100 mL/day on day 1 to between 750 and 800 mL/day by 1 month postpartum.6 During each breastfeed, milk ejection, triggered by the release of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary, delivers milk in a transient fashion to the suckling infant.7 Removal of this milk by the infant is thought to occur early in the breastfeed.8 Consequently, a breastfeed is typically composed of both periods during which the infant removes milk: nutritive sucking (NS), when milk flow rates vary considerably8; and non-nutritive sucking (NNS), periods devoid of milk flow, when only saliva is swallowed.9 Therefore, it is likely that SSwB coordination varies as a result of changing milk flow across a breastfeed, and thus, conventional descriptions suggesting that optimal SSwB ratios are 1:1:1 or 2:1:1 are questionable.

One would expect that with maturation, SSwB coordination may change as the infant ages. This hypothesis is certainly reflected in the fact that infant feeding matures from a reflexive process to one of voluntary control during the first year of life.10 Although it has been established that breastfeeding infants become more effective at feeding as they age by reducing their feed duration, the role of vacuum is less clear.11 Despite Taki et al showing that breastfeeding infants apply similar vacuum levels during the first 6 months postpartum, the influence of both NS and NNS has not been considered.11

Feeding studies have consistently shown that during a swallow, breathing is temporarily interrupted, resulting in a decrease in breathing rate and tidal volume.12 Dittrichova et al showed respiratory rates were similar for the first 4 months postpartum,13 yet how respiratory patterns change within a breastfeed has not been investigated despite the importance of maintaining adequate oxygen saturation levels. Likewise, although oxygen saturation and heart rate levels during breastfeeding have been shown to be superior to those during bottle-feeding,14 it is not known whether the infant achieves this state by regular pausing, and/or interspersing NNS, or by some other mechanism.

Therefore, this study aimed to measure whether breastfeeding infants changed their sucking, swallowing, breathing, oxygenation, and heart rate patterns during the first 4 months postpartum with respect to NS, NNS, and pausing. We proposed that infants would become more efficient at breastfeeding over time as a result of changes in vacuum, and changes in proportions of NS, NNS, and pausing during a feed.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Breastfeeding mother–infant dyads were recruited through the Child and Adolescent Community Health Centre (Oceanic Area Health Service), Perth, Western Australia and via email notification at The University of Western Australia. Infants were required to be healthy, full term (gestational age > 37 wk), and without either breastfeeding difficulties or oral abnormalities. Participants supplied written, informed consent to participate in the study, and ethics approval was obtained from the Human Research Ethics Committee at The University of Western Australia.

Participants visited the lactation research laboratory at King Edward Memorial Hospital, Perth. Each infant was monitored on 2 occasions, once during early lactation when the infant was less than 1 month postpartum and again in later lactation, between 2 and 4 months postpartum. Synchronized recordings of intra-oral vacuum, tongue movement, respiration, oxygen saturation, and heart rate were made for the entire breastfeed, and milk intake was measured.

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: Submental ultrasound imaging of the infant’s intra-oral cavity was used to determine both tongue action and milk flow during all monitored breastfeeds using a Toshiba SSA-770A/80, Aplio 80 (Tokyo, Japan) ultrasound machine with an endocavity convex transducer (PVT-661VT) and Parker Ultrasonic Gel (Fairfield, New Jersey, USA). This method, described in more detail elsewhere,15 enabled a clear view of the nipple, tongue, hard palate, soft palate, and milk flow into the intra-oral cavity.

Intra-oral vacuum was measured using a small silicone tube (Supplemental Nursing System, Medela AG, Baar, Switzerland) filled with sterile water. One end was placed alongside the mother’s nipple and extended 1-2 mm beyond the tip) and the other end was attached via a silicone tube (650 mm × 4 mm) and a 3-way tap to a pressure transducer (SP854, Memscap, Bernin, France) with disposable clip-on dome (MLA844, AD Instruments, Castle Hill, Australia).15

Patterns of respiration and swallowing were measured using respiratory inductive plethysmography (Respitrace QDC, SensorMedics, Yorba Linda, California, USA) from 2 bands attached to the infant, and connected to the Respitrace. One band was secured around the thorax at the level of the nipples and a second around the abdomen at the level of the umbilicus. Oxygen saturation (Sp02) and heart rate were recorded using pulse oximetry16 (Radical/MasimoSET V4.1) with a pediatric sensor (LNOP YI Multisite) taped to the distal end of the infant’s foot.17

At each assessment, milk intake was determined by weighing the infant before and after breastfeeding using an electronic baby weigh scale (Medela AG, Baar, Switzerland, resolution 2 g, accuracy ± 0.034%). Milk intake (g) was calculated by subtracting the initial weight from the final weight.18

Outputs from the ultrasound machine, pressure transducer, respiratory inductive plethysmography, and pulse oximeter were synchronized by LactaSearch, a customized computerized data collection system (LactaSearch, Medela AG, Baar, Switzerland), and recorded using the software package DIAdem (version 11.1, National Instruments, Texas, USA, 2009) with a custom-designed program for offline data analysis.19

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: The breastfeed was divided into suck bursts and pauses. Suck bursts were identified as periods of tongue movement with a cyclic vacuum trace between pauses (tongue resting and a flat vacuum trace). A breath was defined as visualization of both an inspiration and expiration. A swallow was identified as a stable signal on the respiratory trace.20 Sucks and pauses were classified as NS if milk flow was observed in the intra-oral cavity; nutritive pausing (NP) if the pause occurred directly after NS; NNS if no milk flow was observed in the intra-oral cavity on ultrasound; and non-nutritive pausing (NNP) for subsequent pauses (Figure 1).17

caption.p: Example of a Synchronized Trace Showing Suck, Swallow, Breathe, Oxygen Saturation (%), and Heart Rate Measurements (bpm) at Early Lactation During (a) Nutritive Sucking and (b) Non-nutritive Sucking.
During nutritive sucking, the infant repeatedly swallows milk. Few swallows are detected during non-nutritive sucking and none during pauses. Abbreviation: Sp02, oxygen saturation.

sec.p: For each suck burst, burst type (NS/NNS), peak vacuum (mean minimum pressure, mmHg), baseline vacuum (mean maximum pressure, mmHg), suck rate (sucks/min), respiratory rate (breaths/min), suck burst duration (s), total burst duration (s), heart rate (beats per min), and oxygen saturation (%) were calculated. For each pause, pause type (NP/NNP), mean vacuum, respiratory rate, pause duration, total pause duration, heart rate, and oxygen saturation were calculated. Bursts and pauses (burst order) were sequentially numbered to allow analysis of patterns across the breastfeed. Transfer rates (g/min) were calculated as milk intake divided by the total breastfeed duration.

The number of sucks (S), swallows (Sw), and breaths (B) were counted for all NS and NNS suck bursts. Suck-swallow-breathe ratios were determined by calculating the ratios of S:Sw and B:Sw relative to 1 swallow, and S:B relative to 1 breath.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Data analysis was performed using R (version 2.9.0, The R Core Team, Vienna, Austria, 2008). The packages nlme (The R Package, 2008) and multcomp21 were used for linear mixed models and general linear hypothesis tests, respectively. Differences were considered significant when P < .05. Summary data are presented as mean ± SD or median (interquartile range).

Milk intake was analyzed using Student’s paired t tests after testing for normality using the Shapiro test. All other variables were compared using linear mixed models to take into account the repeated measurements in each breastfeed. Different baselines (intercept only) for each individual were used as the random effect. After inspection of residual plots, models were transformed if necessary.

For transfer rate and feed duration, possible differences between early and later lactation as well as breast order were tested with an interaction term for visit (early/later lactation) and breast (breast 1/breast 2). For peak/baseline vacuums; the number of sucks, swallows, and breaths; SSwB ratios; sucking rates; total burst duration; respiratory rate; oxygen saturation; and heart rate; possible differences between visit and burst type were tested with an interaction term for visit and burst type (NS/NNS/NP/NNP). Milk flow was assessed as a categorical variable (NS/NNS).

General linear hypothesis tests were used to determine whether peak, baseline, and mean pausing vacuums, burst, and total burst duration differed by visit, and whether they differed by burst type. To determine patterns across the breastfeed, for all variables (excluding transfer rate and feed duration), burst order was considered as an additional interaction term, with visit and burst type.

sec.title: Demographics and Breastfeeding Characteristics
sec.p: Mothers of 15 healthy term infants were recruited (Table 1). Infants were aged 18 ± 6 days and 73 ± 19 days postpartum at early and later lactation, respectively. The total milk intake during monitored breastfeeds did not differ between early and later lactation (P = .15). Total breastfeed duration was shorter (P = .04), and transfer rate was higher (P = .02), at later lactation (Table 2). For all breastfeeds, NNS bursts occurred least frequently at the beginning third of the breastfeed (14%), followed by the middle (35%), and most commonly at the end of the breastfeed (86%).

caption.p: Demographic Characteristics of Infants and Mothers (n = 15)

fn.label: a
fn.p: Breastfeed type assessed at early lactation.

caption.p: Breastfeeding Characteristics at Early and Later Lactation

fn.label: a
fn.p: P < .05 between early and later lactation.

Note: Data are presented as mean (SD) or median (interquartile). Milk intake was analyzed using Student’s paired t tests. Breast (first/second) was included in the feed duration and transfer rate models and was not significant. Raw data of transfer rate are presented, however, analysis was performed on logged data.

sec.title: Stage of Lactation and Burst Type
sec.p: At later lactation, pause durations were shorter (NP/NNP; P < .001) and suck burst durations were longer (NS/NNS; P < .001) than during early lactation. Nutritive sucking bursts were longer than NNS, NP, and NNP durations for both early and later lactation (P < .001). The total burst durations became shorter at later lactation (NS: P = .02; NP/NNP: P < .001), excluding NNS (P = .89; Table 3), and the total burst duration of NS was significantly longer than that of NNS (P = .001), NP (P = .002), and NNP (P < .001).

caption.p: Total Duration of Sucking and Pausing at Early and Later Lactation

fn.p: Abbreviations: NNP, non-nutritive pausing; NNS, non-nutritive sucking; NP, nutritive pausing; NS, nutritive sucking.

fn.label: a
fn.p: P < .05 between early and later lactation. bP < .05 compared to NS.
Note: Data are presented as median (interquartile range). Raw data are presented, however, analysis was performed on logged data.

sec.title: Vacuum
sec.p: Average levels of peak, baseline, and pause vacuums were associated with both visit and burst type (NS/NNS or NP/NNP; Figure 2). At later lactation, peak, baseline, and mean pausing vacuums became weaker compared to early lactation (all burst types P < .001; Figure 2). At early lactation, peak vacuum was similar between burst types (P = .20), but in later lactation, NS was stronger than NNS (P < .001). At early lactation, baseline vacuum was stronger during NNS (P < .001), but in later lactation, vacuum levels between burst types were similar (P = .63). At early lactation, pausing vacuum was stronger during NNP than NP (P = .002), but in later lactation, vacuum levels were similar between burst types (P > .99; Figure 2).

caption.p: Significant Relationships for Vacuum between Burst Type and Visit. Average Vacuum Levels for (a) Peak, (b) Baseline, and (c) Pausing Vacuums During Early and Later Lactation.
Abbreviations: NS, nutritive sucking; NNS, non-nutritive sucking; NP, nutritive pausing; NNP, non-nutritive pausing.
aP < .05 for interaction with burst type and visit

sec.title: Suck, Swallow, and Breathe Patterns
sec.p: The number of sucks (P < .001) and breaths (P = .03) per burst was higher at later lactation, and the number was greater during NS than NNS (sucks/breaths: P < .001; Table 4). The number of swallows per burst was higher at later lactation for NS only (interaction: P = .04). The S:Sw ratio was higher during NNS than NS, and this effect was greater at later lactation (interaction: P = .01). The B:Sw (P < .001) and S:B (P = .003) ratios were greater during NNS than NS, but they did not change between early and later lactation (B:Sw: P = .40, S:B: P = .30; Table 4).

caption.p: Suck-Swallow-Breathe Characteristics between Early and Later Lactation

fn.p: Abbreviations: NNS, non-nutritive sucking; NS, nutritive sucking; S, suck; Sw, swallow.

fn.label: a
fn.p: P < .05 between early and later lactation.bP < .05 between NS and NNS.cP < .05 for interaction with burst type and visit.
Note: Data are presented as median (IQR). Raw data are presented for swallows per burst and S:Sw, however, analysis of was performed on logged data.

sec.p: Suck rates were faster during NNS than NS (P < .001), with no difference between early and later lactation (P = .38). Respiratory rates were associated with visit and burst type; they were faster during NNS than NS, with different changes between early and later lactation for each burst type (interaction: P < .001; Figure 3).

caption.p: Significant Relationships with Burst Type and Visit (a) Suck Rate, (b) Respiratory Rate, (c) Oxygen Saturation, and (d) Heart Rate.
Abbreviations: NS, nutritive sucking; NNS, non-nutritive sucking; NP, nutritive pausing; NNP, non-nutritive pausing.
cP < .05 for interaction with burst type and visit.

sec.title: Oxygen Saturation and Heart Rate
sec.p: At later lactation, oxygen saturation was higher (P < .001) and heart rate was lower (P < .001). Oxygen saturation during NS (P = .40) and NP (P = .70) was not significantly different from that during NNS. Heart rate was significantly higher during NS (P = .002) and NP (P < .001) compared to NNS (Figure 3).

sec.title: Vacuum.
sec.p: Peak vacuums did not change across the breastfeed (P = .34). Baseline vacuums typically strengthened across breastfeeds, with the exception of NNS at late lactation (interaction: P = .01). Pausing vacuums became stronger across the breastfeed (P < .001).

sec.title: Suck rates and respiratory rates.
sec.p: Suck rates increased across the breastfeed, with the exception of NNS at early lactation (interaction: P = .03). Respiratory rates typically did not change during the breastfeed, with the exception of NS at later lactation (interaction: P = .001).

sec.title: Duration.
sec.p: Suck burst durations decreased across the breastfeed, with the largest effect seen during NS, (interaction: P < .001). Pause durations increased across the breastfeed (P < .001).

sec.title: Sucks, swallows, and breaths.
sec.p: The number of sucks (interaction: P = .03), swallows (interaction: P = .02), and breaths (interaction: P = .001) per burst decreased across the breastfeed during NS, especially at later lactation. The number of S:Sw stayed similar across the breastfeed at early lactation, but increased across the breastfeed at later lactation (interaction: P = .009). There was no difference in the number of B:Sw (P = .30) or S:B (P = .60).

sec.title: Oxygen saturation and heart rate.
sec.p: Oxygen saturation decreased across the breastfeed (P = .01). Heart rate changed across the breastfeed differently for visit and burst type, with NS/NP decreasing at early lactation, and increasing at later lactation. The reverse was shown for NNS/NNP (interaction: P = .01).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study has confirmed that term breastfeeding infants became more efficient at breastfeeding during the first 4 months postpartum, transferring a similar amount of milk from the breast over a shorter period of time by increasing the length of suck bursts and decreasing the time spent pausing. Infants demonstrated satisfactory SSwB coordination during the early postpartum period, however, they showed a level of either adaption or conditioning by applying weaker vacuum levels and demonstrating improved cardiorespiratory responses with age.

sec.title: Burst Patterns
sec.p: Infants increased their breastfeeding efficiency during the first 4 months postpartum by increasing their suck burst durations and reducing pause durations (Table 3). This change resulted in a shorter total feed duration and an increased rate of milk transfer, which supports previous findings related to breastfeeding efficiency.11,22,23 Elevated heart rates and lower oxygenation in younger infants suggest that at this stage of development, infants may need to pause more during milk removal to maintain adequate oxygenation. It appears that this requirement diminishes with age, enabling the infant to more efficiently breastfeed.

Infants showed clear differences in burst patterns between NS and NNS. The longer suck bursts during NS reflect infants’ adaption to milk flow during milk ejection.24 Additionally, the older infants spent more time NS compared to NNS, and even less time pausing, and therefore, most of the breastfeed was spent actively removing milk. Despite this finding, oxygenation levels were maintained, indicating that there is a balance between pausing to recover from active sucking and maintaining efficiency.

sec.title: Vacuum Patterns
sec.p: In contrast to previous studies,11,22,25-27 we showed all baseline and peak and mean pausing vacuums weakened with age. On the other hand, preterm infants have been shown to exert stronger vacuum with increasing gestational age, although this difference may reflect normal development.25,26 Generally, term infants have demonstrated consistent vacuum levels as they age; however, most of these studies were performed on bottle-fed infants,22,27 or they were studies that did not distinguish between NS and NNS during breastfeeding.11 Baseline vacuum is thought to be necessary to seal to the breast and position and elongate the nipple in the oral cavity to facilitate milk removal. Peak vacuum is necessary for milk removal and milk clearance. As peak vacuum is applied, milk flows from the nipple, and as the vacuum is released (decreasing strength), milk is cleared from the oral cavity.15,19 It is possible that the level of vacuum required for both milk removal and clearance is altered with changing maternal and infant factors during lactation. Baseline vacuum might be affected by physical changes of the maternal nipple (increased flexibility, reduced density) that alter the positioning of the nipple,19 whereas peak vacuum could be influenced by developmental changes including reducing oral reflex responses,28 the size of the oral cavity, mandibular growth, and the ability of the tongue to create a larger intra-oral space.29 Further study would be required to assess the influences of these factors on infant sucking.

Ultrasound imaging clearly showed that NNS occurred at various times during the breastfeed, and most commonly at the end of the breastfeed (86% of measured infants). Little NNS at the beginning of the breastfeed indicates that milk ejection probably occurred before the infant latched to the breast and concurs with McNeilly’s measurement of maternal plasma oxytocin peaks prior to breastfeeding.30 Breastfeeding infants have traditionally been described to suck in a biphasic pattern; the first phase (NNS) occurs prior to the initial milk ejection, leading to the second phase (NS).3 Using this definition, Mizuno et al showed that NNS was significantly stronger than NS during breastfeeding (peak: –96 mmHg vs –74.5 mmHg).3 In contrast, when observing NNS throughout the breastfeed, we found that peak vacuum was similar between NS and NNS early in lactation, and that NNS became weaker than NS later in lactation (Figure 2). These results contrast with current assumptions3,31 and suggest that NNS can occur throughout the breastfeed. However, it is not known how vacuum levels vary with changing levels of milk flow during a breastfeed.

sec.title: Suck-Swallow-Breathe Coordination
sec.p: Suck-swallow-breathe coordination did not change as infants aged in that suck rates, B:Sw ratio, and S:B ratio were similar in early and later lactation, indicating coordination is developed from 2-4 weeks postpartum in term breastfeeding infants. Changes, such as the greater number of sucks, swallows, and breaths during NS, were likely to be a reflection of the longer bursts during milk removal when the infants were older. Previously, it has been assumed that SSwB coordination improves with age, however, this improved coordination has been established mainly in bottle-feeding studies and those assessing preterm infants.25,26 Our results indicate that from the early postpartum period onward, coordination is developed in healthy term breastfeeding infants.

It is logical to assume that the ability to rapidly change SSwB coordination in response to fluctuating milk flow will result in more efficient breastfeeding. We certainly found lower S:B, B:Sw, and S:Sw ratios; suck and respiratory rates; and more frequent swallowing during NS compared to NNS. Together with the results of Scheel et al,32 who showed that bottle-fed preterm infants were able to modify their sucking pattern and SSwB coordination depending on the rate of milk flow, our study supports the notion that breastfeeding infants are capable of adapting SSwB coordination to the rapidly changing flow rates encountered at milk ejection.33

sec.title: Heart Rate and Oxygenation
sec.p: Heart rate was higher in younger infants in this study, suggesting that there is a conditioning effect to breastfeeding as the infant ages. Lappi et al also showed heart rate was highest at 6 weeks postpartum and decreased by 6 months during bottle-feeding.34 The authors concluded that increased heart rate was a response to milk removal being a physical task that increases cardiac output to enable optimal sucking, and they suggested that sucking may function as a stimulus for cardiovascular regulation. In this study, since values for both early and later lactation were within a normal clinical range, it is not clear whether the changes reflect a conditioning effect or the general maturation of the infant. We suspect that both these factors are important.

Although heart rate is known to increase during infant feeding,34,35 most studies have relied on bottles or pacifiers to measure NNS as a comparison to NS; on the other hand, we measured heart rate during NS and NNS in breastfeeding infants and found that heart rates were higher during NS compared to NNS, especially during the first month postpartum. Our results again indicate that breastfeeding is more demanding during milk removal.

Despite the infants in this study maintaining high oxygenation at all times during early and later lactation, we found oxygenation increased with age. This finding most likely reflects normal maturation, as oxygen saturation during breastfeeding, while sleeping, and while awake has been shown to increase across the first 8 weeks postpartum.36,37 Interestingly, we did not detect a decrease in oxygenation during NS despite showing a significant increase in heart rate, suggesting excellent coordination of the infant. These results therefore imply a level of maturity and/or conditioning as the infant ages.36,37

sec.title: Patterns during the Breastfeed
sec.p: We expected to see changes in feeding parameters during the breastfeed as a result of reducing milk flow during a feed, and indeed, suck bursts became shorter, pauses became longer, suck rates became faster, and fewer sucks and swallows per burst were observed for both early and later lactation during the breastfeed. Shorter suck bursts and longer pauses are likely to be indicative of infant satiety, fatigue, and milk availability. Our results support those of others, in which both breastfed infants and expressing mothers remove at least half of their total milk intake/available milk in the first 4 or 5 minutes of either the breastfeed or expression.8,35 Interestingly, peak vacuum levels remained relatively constant during the breastfeed, whereas baseline and pausing vacuums increased. This finding may indicate that the peak vacuum required to expand the nipple and increase milk duct size within the nipple does not change,38 whereas decreasing milk flow during a breastfeed may result in the infant applying a stronger baseline vacuum to elongate the nipple and maintain optimal positioning. The fact that oxygen saturation decreased during the breastfeed may also reflect the infant’s energy required to maintain baseline vacuum. Patterns during the breastfeed are therefore likely to be influenced by changes in milk flow, breast emptying, infant fatigue, and satiety.

Limitations of this study include the small sample size and large age range measured at later lactation. However, the repeated-measures approach enabled researchers to investigate for the first time changes that occurred during the entire breastfeed. Similarly, the study assessed 2 time points during lactation; it is possible that changes in infant maturation may have occurred either prior or subsequent to our measurements. Likewise, the influence of birth mode on SSwB coordination has not been documented. It is not currently possible to measure milk flow from the breast, therefore NS and NNS were classified as a categorical variable (the presence or absence of milk). Future measurement of milk flow rate from the breast would enable milk flow to be assessed as a continuous variable and thereby provide a more detailed understanding of how SSwB coordination may be affected by milk ejection.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Healthy term infants became more efficient at breastfeeding during the first 4 months postpartum. They achieved this increased efficiency primarily by increasing their suck burst duration and decreasing the time spent pausing. Despite infants in the study showing a high level of SSwB coordination in the first month postpartum, they had stronger vacuum levels and higher heart rates during this period compared to later in lactation. We conclude that a level of either conditioning or adaption to breastfeeding occurs over time, which requires further investigation.

ack.p: We thank the participating breastfeeding mothers and infants for their time and Ms Tracey Williams’s assistance during data collection.
